commentBody: does anyone else have a keyboard underneath their puzzle?  It's awful and takes up too much space.  How do I get rid of it?
When I open the puzzle today, there is a keyboard below the puzzle, how do I get it to go away?
I see people are having a problem with a phantom keyboard below the puzzle.  I just want to note that I didn‚Äôt seem to have that problem.  It looks the same as always on my iPhone .
Lot's of fun with clever double definitions.  Great Tuesday!
I see the keyboard. I want to print out the puzzle. Anyone know what's going on?

[Pick your courtroom drama]
MOTIONPICTURE

"Forest Gump"
WALKIETALKIE
That keyboard is driving me mad. Please -- how do I get rid of it??

Lego enthusiasts have to learn the bricks of the trade.

(These puns call for plastic measures.)

Is this a new redesign that's being rolled out today...? If it is, it's horribly formatted for PC or laptop screens ‚Äì the actual crossword is microscopic as compared to everything flanking it on the sides and beneath, and the keyboard doesn't even do anything. 

Why do computer users even need an on-screen keyword? Is this a glitch......?
I get an error saying the puzzle will not fit on my laptop screen, a useless puzzle.
I DO NOT LIKE the new format. Please make it optional.  Thank you!

Yes, there a keyboard under the puzzle. In addition, the puzzle is not playable on my laptop screen. The clues are on either side of the grid, there is no repetition of the current clue above the grid, and everything is much too small to read. When I enlarge the image I get a message telling me to rotate my screen (what??).  I hope this is a fixable error and not a new format, because it is useless to me.

Haha, an unintended laugh out loud, after yesterday, to see the clue for the PLASTIC FILM.

And then, just look at 22D!
Don‚Äôt the editors realize that the third-person conjugation of OGLE is OGLE?

A splendid debut. The play on film titles made for a breezy, fun, perfect Tuesday solve. Come back soon, Mr. Benson.

Along with others, I truly hope the fomatting issues are quickly resolved. My attempts to open any puzzle on a laptop (the current puzzle and previously solved puzzles) are met with an "Oh no! We can't fit everything on your screen. Please rotate your device" error message. I had to solve this puzzle on my tablet -- definitely do-able, but not my preferred device.

I read (past tense like Lego and ogle) through all the comments before I wrote my post. Apparently the ease of doing this on my phone has saved me some issues tonight.
I found this a delightful Tuesday with a few tricky clues. I tend not to watch the Simpsons or pay attention to titles so I had yello instead of yells. Aside from that I tried watering rescues instead of Features for Finding Nemo but both were quickly resolved. I look forward to more puzzles by Mr Benson.

This new format is the New Coke of crosswords.  
If it ain't broke, don't fix it.
Anyone else have the Laverne and Shirley opening theme song stuck in their head now?  üòÑ

Here's the SNL parody of the Nicole Kidman AMC promo: - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a22c8NPNOPI There are a few reasons I only go to see movies in theaters a couple of times a year, but her promotional spot definitely played a small role ;)

Loved the puzzle, kudos to the constructor.
Hate the new format. It is not an improvement in any way.

Enjoyable Tuesday, for sure!

Definitely got the benefit of a couple repeats of recent clue/answer pairs.
Using a MacBook Air and opening the puzzle in Firefox, I have no issues. It looks the same as it has always looked.
This is terrible. Please put it back the way it was.

The format change in today's puzzle was an unwelcome surprise. I do the crossword on a laptop where a keyboard on the screen is absolutely useless (I understand that it's useful for other devices, but surely there could be an option for something like tablet mode?). I suppose I could get used to having clues on both sides of the grid, but it takes time away from solving when I have to change my view from one side to the other while solving rather than moving slightly up and down on the same side of the grid. I hope this was a glitch, but if this was a deliberate re-design, please go back to the drawing board.
Fun one!

Uncanny how some of the answers in today's puzzles were similarly in puzzles earlier this week, including ET TU, ALMA, Langston Hughes's "I TOO," and the echo of yesterday's LEGO controversy. Am I wrong in thinking this is the only occasion where I can safely say that we've had two LEGOS in a row here? Or is it still two LEGO in a row? Just yanking your chain.

I never knew from water feature
and I never hope to see one, 
but if it came to becoming such a creature,
I'd rather see than be one.

I would've thought the Vatican would be the smallest yada yada, but no, it turns out they're not part of the EU, despite using the Euro as their currency. 

Like last Tuesday this one had some mmmmph to it, and while I don't really find much delight in the themers, I liked the pushback in the cluing, and felt tested. You had to know some slightly weird stuff to get through this puzzle, and I can imagine it making some solvers slightly plaintive. Ah well, there's a lot to be plaintive about these days. Word of the day: LIAR.

I, fortunately, have not experienced the layout bug, and I've done both the Monday and Tuesday puzzles. Wondered if it was OS-related because iOS apps can sometimes be run on Apple Silicon Macs, but both my old Intel iMac and my newer M1 MacBook Air were showing the "usual" webpage graphics.

As for the puzzle, I found it a little bit crunchy, but definitely doable. Nice to see another new face, and very nice debut puzzle.

Thanks, Bob!

So you all are saying the new layout is‚Ä¶ NOT GREAT, BOB!

(The crossword was fine, I just had to use that line because of the constructor‚Äôs name.)
Why is no one commenting on Malta being the answer for smallest country in the EU? It‚Äôs not even the second smallest in the EU? Am I missing something?

Really really hate the new layout. Keyboard on screen while solving on a computer is 1) useless 2) takes up a bunch of screen real estate. Also, the on-screen keyboard didn't even work???

The clues split to left and right is something I think I could get used to, but for now it makes it a lot harder to check crosses while solving an area - I basically end up focusing on the lists one at a time and viewing the grid in my periphery. With the two column across/down list you could view both at once while doing this, but now my vision constantly has to sweep from the left to right side of the screen. Also, the lists are super short in height because the keyboard takes up so much space. It's really really bad.

Also what happened to the San Jose Strut‚ÄΩ‚ÄΩ‚ÄΩ‚ÄΩ‚ÄΩ‚ÄΩ‚ÄΩ‚ÄΩ‚ÄΩ

After having read the horror stories on my phone, I expected a disaster when I opened up the web page for the NYT crossword on my MacBook Air, expecting to see the problem.

But it all looks like normal to me.  Does anyone know if this is only affecting PCs at this point?

Congratulations on a fine NYT debut, Mr. Benson! Sorry to see that your puzzle‚Äôs charms are lost in the (totally justified) complaints about the layout of the web version of the puzzle. 

I hope we‚Äôll see you back soon.
STIES are where pigs live. STyES are something different. Wonder if I was the only one who spent lots of time figuring that out.

The new layout is terrible. I have a very difficult time using it. I cannot adjust it to make the clues readable for both my wife and myself can see it. The keyboard is useless to me. I see no way to eliminate it. 

Please give an option to get rid of the keyboard and go back to the old layout.

Looks like this is not the day to leggo our LEGO.

Sorry for those who are experiencing technical difficulties, because this was an enjoyable puzzle and a solid debut. Welcome, Bob! Hope you come back to play again soon.
We loved today‚Äôs puzzle! How about ‚ÄúKing Kong‚Äù?  _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ (10)  ü§≠

Is anyone else frustrated with the new layout of the crossword?  My online screen now has across clues left of the board, down clues to the right, and a giant onscreen keyboard that takes up 1/2 the screen, reducing the size of the board significantly.  Is it just me?  Did I accidentally toggle some option that turned on the onscreen keyboard?  If so, I can't figure out how to turn it back off.  Who needs a giant onscreen keyboard when you have on the laptop itself?  This new layout has slowed down solving a lot.  I have to glance back and forth to the clues, and squint at the tiny board now.  Is there a way to switch back to the old layout?
Congrats on the NYT debut! This was a fun one. I really liked BARMENU for "spirit guide."
Perfect Tuesday level and congratulations on the debut, Bob! I enjoyed your labor of love. Looking forward to seeing more from you.

I got stumped on some of the fill and had to rework my entries here and there. And that's a compliment, Mr. Benson. A bit of a challenge on a Tuesday is always welcome. Kudos to you on a fine puzzle. Now that you've crossed it off your bucket list, please write in "Get even more puzzles published in the NYT." We'll be anxiously awaiting them! (The musical accompaniment today is another Mr. Benson - the guitar virtuoso, George Benson https://youtu.be/6jdH1T8hc9c?si=peYiJm-YMgzB8i3V)

This was Wednesday difficulty for me with all the names and abbreviations. I don't get FTS for military installations, and I have no idea what a FRIARS CLUB is, for example, so the crossing of the two on the first letter was nasty, and my last square to fall (bRIARS seemed plausible to me). Not knowing schlemiel and the tv channel in the quadrant directly W complicated things, too. 

How is VCR a device with tracking tech? I'm obviously not understanding something (also, VCR... I haven't had one for 20 years!)

The online puzzle format on PC is dreadfully ill-conceived 

- The enormously oversized on-screen keyboard is non-functional, either by touchscreen or mouse.
- The puzzle display has been reduced in size to near invisibility
- The separation and lack of synchronization between "across" and "down" clues is disconcerting and difficult to work with. 

Please make the old format available and consider improving it with more practical changes, such as scalable fonts,  adjustable column widths, and an expandable active clue field.

Congrats on your debut Bob Benson. It was a great Tuesday for me and I thought the theme was clever. Like a few others, I did get stuck on the first letter of 11A/D but F was my second guess so not too painful. 

Re yesterday's puzzle, I didn't see anyone mention Corrections, any other jackals here? (For those not in the know, Seth Meyers started an online feature responding to comments after a correction about Legos/Lego bricks)

Great puzzle with punny long solves! Fun fact, other than cameras and office equipment, RICOH used to produce really good quality watches with their own mechanical movements, which is not what a lot of swiss brands can claim. I love their dynamic wide series, perfect budget alternatives to Rolex; there's a lot swimming around on eBay and japanese auction sites

Please remove the on-screen keyboard. I have an actual keyboard. I don't need two. It makes the grid miniscule. Sunday's will be impossible.
Thank you.

Pretty chewy for a Tuesday;  looking at you 11A/D, 42A, et al. Still enjoyable though.
TIL there was a button for tracking on VCRs. Don‚Äôt think that was a thing in the UK. Is it because there were different systems? We had, I think, PAL. 
I love learning new Yiddish expressions. I‚Äôd heard Schlemiel, but now I know what it means!
Took me an embarrassingly long time to figure out Eeyore‚Äôs malady; Dismal? Gloomy? 

Off to feed the alpacas. Destructo-dog finally left yesterday, so the girls can relax. The chickens had to put up with her barking at them too, but they just glared at her and carried on. Our poor, middle aged Shiba has been flat out by the Aga since the Lab left; she was basically a teenager, stamping her feet, swinging  her hair and crying ‚Äúit‚Äôs not FAIR!‚Äù Every 5 minutes. Can‚Äôt wait for grandchildren üòØ

Didn't have any of the PC format issues others are commenting on - maybe because I use Firefox and possibly it was sorted out before I started?

Love the puzzle today - only took a bit longer than usual because I forget the differences in spelling words such SOMBER (sombre) and PROGRAM (programme, unless its a computer). 

Silly mistake, as I've been doing NYT crosswords for a long time now.
I absolutely DO NOT LIKE the new format that showed up this morning, how do I get it back to where it was? I solve on a lap top and have NO NEED for an onscreen keyboard!
In addition to my prior comments, the whole onscreen keyboard situation doesn't even work!

Congratulations on your debut, Bob.  I thought it was a little stickier than the usual Tuesday, and appreciated that.  

Hope to see you back soon.

Fun puzzle - all in the clues. Had to work some crosses for each of the theme answers, but that just made for nice 'aha' moments as each of them dawned on me. Really enjoyed it. And my puzzle find today was another 'all in the clues' type. I'm sure I did this one but had forgotten it. Anyway - a Sunday from March 19, 2023 by Robert Ryan with the title "Give me a break!" Some clue/answer examples: "Zone out?" DEPARTMENTALLY "Seat at the dining table?" SUPPOSITION "Beauty that runs in the family?" KINESTHETIC "Boys' club?" MALEFACTION "Swindle by instant messaging?" CONTEXTUALLY And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/19/2023&g=23&d=A I'm done. ....

As someone who still owns and uses VCRs, 43D made me laugh. (don't worry, I have DVD, Blu-ray, digital, and streaming devices as well).
Nice misdirection on that one!

A very pleasant puzzle. Some clever cluing, but not too tricky, and a fun theme. 

I feel bad for those who are having format issues, it's a glitch they are working to fix, so at least it's not permanent.
Hate the onscreen keyboard! How do I get rid of it?
Wonderful puzzle. Enjoyed it so much. Congrats on your first puzzle. Looking forward to many more.
Please get the layout back! I hate the keyboard showing on my laptop. I'm too old for new tricks. ;)
The new user interface for the browser interferes with the solving experience.  Horrible.  Please revert to the normal layout.
Refused to play today due to keyboard on screne layout. Happening in both Edge and Chrome. Time to cancel my subcription I guess . Totally unworkable.

I had the format with the big keyboard too, and also Wordle and Spelling Bee are behaving like the mobile version (on Chrome). It started yesterday evening - at first, I couldn't even log into the Games site; it thought I didn't have a subscription, but when I clicked on "subscribe", it said I was already subscribed, so I was in an endless loop. Then, when I was finally able to log in, all the games were the mobile version.  Hopefully this gets fixed soon.

Clever, charming Tuesday.
Lovely debut!

Woke up after my first night taking
the blood pressure medication my doc
says I now need.

I pouted. and waited a week.

Last night, took it, and went to bed.
Holy shamoly!
Slept like a baby!

So maybe this was the most friendly
Tuesday puzzle ever,
and/or
I got a beautiful night‚Äôs rest.

Aah‚Ä¶

Hoping you all have some lovely moments today!

What in the name of all that's holy is going on? That new screen is causing me all kinds of neck pain as I try to see the clues which are now a tenth of the size of the keys on the completely unnecessary, unusable (I don't have a touch screen computer!) keyboard. My time is longer because I can't see the across and down clues at the same time. The space is just bizarrely organized, and I'm being kind here. At least give players an option for the old interface!

Yikes!
Just read a few comments!

I solve on an iPad.
Nothing was different today.

So sorry that messed up the solve
for so many! 
Just a bummer!
Really enjoyed the playful film/tv clues. Well done!

My screen on my iPad looks the same as it always does, a shame it‚Äôs causing trouble for so many as it is a fine debut puzzle, just right for Tuesday I think.  I also really enjoyed Bob's notes and look forward to more puzzles from him.

checking the comments, I am having the same problem - I play on my pc laptop, all of a sudden I can not open the wordle, or the puzzles...what is going on...hopefully the issue will be resolved as I don't like to play on my iphone.

Two where are they now answers today -

1) I was always wondering where Bob Benson from accounts wound up
2) I guess we now know what former Sonos CEO Patrick Spence is up to - the new format people are complaining about is exactly how most people feel about the new Sonos app!  Thank goodness this seems to have been fixed.

I don't know what anyone is talking about with the new format: I played the game on Signal and every time I put down a word, Marco Rubio and Pete Hegseth sent me messages saying "Great job, John Ezra!" with clapping hands emojis. It was so much fun!

OH MY GOODNESS!! The new format is very disturbing. My think pad turned my grid into a tiny blip on the screen and the keyboard is the size of Montana.  Please go back to the old format?????  PLEASE??????  That said, the puzzle was fun!

I have some serious issues with 31A.

First of all, there is no such thing as a "perch plant." Yes, perhaps there are canneries that process fish for mass distribution, but they hardly limit themselves to perch. It would make no economic sense.

Also, anyone who would bake a "perch pie" would be certifiably insane.

So, of course, the answer is "sill," which I suppose is some super-obscure fisherman's term for a perch. But how am I supposed to know it? An exhaustive Google search retrieves only a handful of cases in which the word sill is used in this way.

A pity, too, because otherwise this is a fine Tuesday puzzle. But recently I have learned from John Cena not to tolerate any abuse. So leave the perch out of it!!!!!
An APLUS debut.  Congratulations.

It‚Äôs a wow theme for me.  Here you have a term for something you watch on a screen clued with the title of an example of the term ‚Äì and an answer that‚Äôs an in-the-language phrase totally unrelated to movies or tv.

That is sophisticated and clever. High props to Bob for coming up with it. 

It may also be tight, that is, a set of worthy theme answers that are hard to add to. The best I could come up with is the tepid [‚ÄúApollo 13‚Äù?] for HIGH DRAMA.  Bob, you said your original submission was a Sunday puzzle ‚Äì can you chime in and tell us what other theme answers you came up with?

I liked seeing the contradictory cross of CACKLE and SAD SACK, and the rhyming LIAR, FRIAR, and IRE.  It‚Äôs also sweet to see three promising debut puzzles in a row ‚Äì the gift of new Crosslandia voices.  

Congratulations on your impressive debut, Bob.  Thank you for a splendid outing!
Don't like the new format. It's invade The Mini too. Please go back to the old way. Messing with my laptop.

I'm going to add to all the hatred of the new format that, as a lawyer, I can attest that you are just begging for a lawsuit from a paying subscriber for drastically reducing accessibility for people who are visually or haptically disabled.
Nice puzzle. One nit: there were only 2 Gershwins, so the clue should have been, "Older Gershwin brother."
I accidentally clicked on REBUS, and then it would never go away. All squares became rebuses. I had to close the tab and reopen the puzzle to make it stop.

Nice puzzle.
Hate the new format. Why do techies always have to mess with stuff that works and make it worse?
I'm with Diane. The keyboard is annoying. Let us turn it off by a simple button. Why presume that you know better than we what we prefer?

Hi Deb, Co Crocker here.  Maybe you remember me from the "Old " NYT Forum days?  As you can probably guess, I have found my way back here for a singular reason.  The new format is simply awful.  Please pass my feeling to those who matter.  I have completed every NYT crossword since the beginning of 1997 .  I have never missed one.  I am old, tired and grumpy and this new hodgepodge makes me want to quit.  I hope you and the old gang are all well.

On a new laptop in Windows 11 using Chrome I get a message to the effect of "Please rotate your device" (from landscape to portrait) for both Mini and regular Crossword. There's a graphic showing what to do.

I could attempt Strands and Connections puzzles as usual. Had to get to Wordplay through the menu this time.
Where are people seeing this new format? Is it in the web browser? I don‚Äôt notice anything different in the NYT Games app.

I‚Äôve been enjoying the mini puzzles they play before this big one.

You know: the Will Shorts?

A good Tuesday puzzle. 
(Is anyone here by mistake? Other than john ezra  ;)
I really dislike the new format.  Please change it back.
Came here to see if it was "just me". Hate the new format. Now I'll go TRY to do the puzzle.

Enjoyed the puzzle however:
Not trilled with clue to 25D. I'm sure you can guess why.
Really had troubles with the SE corner. 

One of my favorite comic strips growing up was 26A. Not sure if I graduated to reading the comic book.
New format doesn't work on my Windows 10 PC with my Chrome browser. Hate it enough to end my subscription.
I am not a fan of the new layout. I hope we will see an option to return to the old format.
No new format for me on MacBook Air. I hope it's not on its way.
I do not like the new format at all.  Hopefully, this is just a test and you will go back to the previous format.  Please!
The new format is terrible. Why fix what is obviously not broken? Please please go back to the old format.
PEOPLE, THE NEW FORMAT IS A MISTAKE See this post from Deb from yesterday. https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/46am6t?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share email crosswordeditors@nytimes.com to complain.

Another pleasant debut puzzle 
for those who were able to see it.

Thanks for taking us to the movies, Bob.


Now let's have a word with the projectionists...

The keyboard feature showed up for me, too. I tried right clicking and selecting inspect so that I can select and delete it, but it isn't working for me. Will you create an option in settings so that we can choose not to have the keyboard show up? I'm using a desktop PC.

Please make a classic mode user interface available. I don't use the touchpad and 1/3 of the screen space is wasted displaying a keyboard. I have bad eyesight and need more screen space for the grid and the clues. Also, it was much slower to solve the puzzle as I had to move my eyes back and forth across the screen to see across vs down clues.
I am happy to report that I've not encountered the "new format."  I use the Chrome browser and everything looks the same to me.

I do feel badly that Bob Benson's nice debut is being overshadowed by everyone's (mine included) dissatisfaction with the website glitch. 
Nice debut, Bob!

Oh, what fun to laugh and sing a solving song today!  
Wasn't this fun, clever, quick, and fresh?
We don't have any RICOH-brand stuff; DHubby says even the cameras are "kind of out of fashion."  (Sometimes Mr. Fix-it wears his Mr. Techie hat.)

Welcome, Bob Benson.  And what great timing--mentioning "The Lego Movie."  IN RE, tsk AS TO-- the PLASTIC bricks...how do you feel about the plural of....  (Hey! Stop throwing things! Ow! That hurt!)

On today's calendar, sewing the labels onto the two quilts.  I used the sewing machines "monogram" program to stitch out given names, birthdates, and nicknames, and Yes, I sign my work. ..for posterity, or (more likely) just the fun of it.  

Wishing us all a productive day!

Wondering why there were 165 comments at 8am on a Tuesday. Aha. (I only solve on Android)

This was pretty tricky for a Tuesday! I had totally forgotten about VCR tracking. For anyone under 35: it was this little dial on your VCR that you could theoretically turn if the playback was fuzzy. 90 percent of the time it did nothing and made it worse as I recall.

I enjoyed the movie theme today! I admit, I still don't know what an FTS is, and I don't habitually watch roasts. I had to guess whether it was Friar or Briar's club. Thankfully I got it on the first try!
Ok, fun Tuesday solve but this gray-haired man objects to OLD being clued as obsolete!
Would someone be so kind as to explain to me what 43D means? I'm old enough to remember our VCR but I don't understand the clue.

If there was ever a group that appreciates the fact that language matters, it's NYT crossword fans.

So to that end‚Äîand please accept this in the spirit in which this is presented ‚Äî I object to using "old" as a definition for "obsolete." It's in these small ways that language subtly shapes how we view people, things, and ideas. Words matter.

Happy to report that I just reopened the completed puzzle, and at least in my setup, the puzzle is displaying properly again.

I'm using Chrome on a Dell desktop of recent vintage, But it seems to work in Edge and Firefox as well.

Hope everyone else is experiencing the same thing!

I have noticed a lot of yiddish or Jewish cultural terms that i have no knowledge of in many puzzles. I don‚Äôt see any references to other religion‚Äôs terms to the same degree. Seems like you are giving short shrift to Catholicism, and others (although perhaps the second most frequent is Islam?). But why such infatuation with these niche terms as compared to other terms (tools, musical instruments, etc) These are also lesser used but known to a certain block (musicians -dobro, woodworkers - dado as examples i run into frequently)
Not a fan of this one at all. Cluing felt amateurish and relied too much on trivia and names. Definitely can tell it‚Äôs a debut. Oh well.
The puzzle's back! Thank you thank you thank you.

In what world is FTS a military installation?  I finished the puzzle by completing the other words but my post-puzzle research did not provide a clue (pun intended).
However, I DID love the movie puns, and the puzzle in general...

I contacted Games support yesterday after it changed to the huge keyboard and split clues, and got this back just now: "Our development team has implemented a correction for the unintended keyboard display. Please refresh your page to apply the fix."

Should be all good now‚Äîit looks good on my end.
For me, this was a perfect puzzle for a Tuesday. Kudos to Mr. Benson.
Too many proper nouns crossing each other and a subpar theme. Not my favorite.

I've never been in the military so am speaking from ignorance, but I often hear phrases like, "They're sending 10,000 troops," meaning 10,000 individual soldiers. So shouldn't the 1A clue just be "Soldiers" rather than "Groups of soldiers"? A troop isn't a group, from how I've heard the term used.

Regarding roasts at the FRIAR'S CLUB, there's a sad and beautiful story about Harry "Parkyakarkus" Einstein, the father of comedians Bob "Super Dave" Einstein and Albert Brooks (n√© Einstein), giving his final performance at the roast of Lucille Ball. Bob Einstein, now best known as Marty Funkhouser from "Curb Your Enthusiasm", tells the story in his second appearance on Jerry Seinfeld's "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee", or you can just watch it on YouTube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KuVA-IbuQiU
Great Tuesday puzzle with just enough bite.

Perhaps the earlier comments helped resolve the bugs for us solvers on the West Coast, because I solved it on my laptop without even realizing there was a glitch. Or perhaps I just totally missed the meta-theme-graphic-pattern that accompanied the puzzle, wouldn't be the first time...  Thanks to those who paved the way by doing the puzzle and reporting the layout issues!

I loved this puzzle, thought there were some tricky but fair and fun clues (yes, "bar menu"), and it was challenging in just the right way. A perfect Tuesday. Thank you, Bob!

My usual late puzzle find, inspired by wondering how often CZECH might have appeared in puzzles. Anyway - a Sunday from November 3, 1991 by Maura B. Jacobson with the title: "International double plays." The clue and answer that led me there: "Plaid, for one" CZECHKURDPATTERN "One more clue/answer example" Note left by a linksman : IWENTGAULFINN And some other theme answers: CROATOMANICOLORS DONTKHMERANYMOOR GRANDKENYANSWEDE SERBTHEMAYANDISH Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/3/1991&g=16&d=D ....

Took a little longer than my usual Tuesday because I thought a schlemiel could be a SCHMUCK, in keeping with the Yiddish theme! But SAD SACK is almost better, you rarely hear that phrase anymore so it got a big smile out of me.

Another late post. This is just amazing. My previous puzzle find eventually led me look at Maura B. Jacobson's page on Xword Info. Three Shortz era puzzles and 63 pre-Shortz puzzles, the vast majority of them Sundays. Her Shortz era puzzles had 19 answers that never appeared in another puzzle. There's no listed stat for her pre-Shortz puzzles but it had to be hundreds I would think. Anyway... just a few answer examples: CROATOMANICOLORS THESEWAGECANAL SOMMEARGONNEFORTH SEOULLYONSMAINERHODES ALCOTTSCHILLUNGOTRHYTHM ILOVEMYWIFEBUTOHEUCLID EUBIESONICETOCOMEHOMETO BLACKCOALOFCALCUTTA GETYOURBERINGSTRAIT THEFORESIGHTSAGA THEJOYOFSECTS LOOKBACKINHANGAR And there were just many, many, many more. Here's her Xword Info page: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Thumbs?author=Maura+B.+Jacobson Worth your time to go take a look. ....

I was getting this message yesterday on the crossword, and couldn't open it:  
"Oh no! We can‚Äôt fit everything on your screen.
Please rotate your device."  

...which is weird because I solve on a laptop.  Today it is fixed and I was able to do the puzzle, but now I have that same message on Wordle.

Anyone else?
Fun puzzle! STIES is new for me. Totally assumed STIRS!

Got it, wordless and the connections too.

About connections, you can group four which are related, but like in school, it isn‚Äôt the answer they are looking for and you‚Äôve blown a turn.    The authors of such should think about that and make it less annoying on occasion.
Might be a GenX thing, but reading 26A and then reading this column immediately made me think of intro to the "Laverne and Shirley" theme song: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bJzF8_df1R8

If you're wondering about the exchange rate thing: please remember the countries behind the Iron Curtain were not part of the world economy. Foreign trade was strictly regulated, and only the government could engage in it. However, "communist" governments borrowed money broad, also from capitalist countries, which traded in dollars. The Polish dictator in the 1970s, Edward Gierek, went on a huge spending spree, building new disctricts in Polish cities (including Warsaw's Ursyn√≥w, where I grew up), new factories, hotels for state-sponsored vacations, etc. Most of the money he needed, he borrowed abroad. By the early 80s he was out, but the country had to repay all that debt, in dollars. So the government did everything it could to get all the dollars it could get its hands on. First, the exchange rate was not up to the market (there was no market economy, remember) - the government set it. So they made it so it made no sense for people to buy dollars from the government, only to sell them to it. Second, the most attractive, luxury goods, like that VCR of ours, were only on sale for dollars in "skelpy dewizowe" (foreign currency shops), further incentivizing people to transfer their dollars to the government (all the shops were state owned). I can't possibly imagine how alien all this must sound to Americans :D For some details, Wiki has an article on Pewex and Baltona, the foreign currency shops: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pewex https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltona

@Janine

@Dawn 
I have never been to NY but know enough about it to do crosswords-through Seinfeld.

@Dawn 

The New York Friars Club was a private club for people in show business, not a comedy club.  The average New Yorker looking for a night out at a comedian's show would not have gone out to the Friars Club, and would probably not even be aware of it as an entity any more so than someone from Tallahassee or Sarasota.

The Friars Club hosted "roasts" for their members, some of whom were granted honorary membership for the privilege.  All of these honorees were extremely famous entertainers, such as Frank Sinatra, Barbra Streisand, Carol Burnett, Lucille Ball and Elizabeth Taylor.  The roasts were shown on network television, and were widely viewed events.  The roasts began in the 1950s, and continued into the new century.

A second Friars Club was established in Beverly Hills and conducted the same type of roasts.  These roasts were also widely televised.

In their heyday, Friars Club roasts were very well known, and associated more with California than New York in their later years.

Hope this clarifies matters.

@JGrey 

In VCRs, "tracking" refers to the calibration adjustment ensuring the playback head is properly aligned with the helical scan signal on the tape, preventing issues like fuzzy images or skipped scenes.
@JGrey You would have to adjust the "tracking" - so that the picture would be stable. It was like a roller-wheel. If the picture was distorted or flipping, the tracking was off
@JGrey The tracking feature was on OLD, more obsolete VCRs. As technology improved, the tracking function was  removed.

@LinRP 

"Old" is not being used as a definition; it is a clue, and clues are not definitions.  A clue is valid if even one sense of the word matches the answer in one way or another, and this is the case here:


You can't use that charger with the new iPhone, it's the OLD one.

You can't use that charger with the new iPhone, it's the OBSOLETE one.


As an "old" myself, I don't want to be considered obsolete, either, but that's the way crossword clues work.  There's rarely exact overlap, and in many cases, it's an intentional misdirect.

David B, You did not learn enough. A troupe and a troop are both a group. Troop as an individual is a common back formation -- MY DI in Basic call me a troop -- but the formal definition is collective. That's why members of a troop are troopers (and members of a troupe troupers). https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/troop

Thanks Eric. I think the article hits on all the key themes.  Top of the list is maintaining, as best we can, physical health and activity, get BP and cholesterol under control (note newer, lower guidelines), etc. etc.  

I've always maintained that my success at the puzzles, or lack thereof, in an indication on how I'm doing with basic heath regimes including diet, avoiding the sauce and better sleep.  When I fall down on those measures the puzzle performance suffers and a signal (not the app!) to do better. 

Social connections?  You betcha there's work to be done as we get older.  I'm working on improving that IRL but have to say that this forum is also a key part of the social network, something many of the commenters on your article mentioned. 

Many thanks for posting the link.
